front.title: Initialization of transport parameters for 0-RTT connections

abstract.t: 0-RTT is designed to reduce the time needed to re-establish a connection. There are cases where 0-RTT alone does not improve the time to service. Moreover, additionnal information could be forwarded to the server to adapt the initial transport parameters.
This memo proposes a solution where an additional parameter is registered during the 1-RTT phase to improve the initial throughput during subsequent 0-RTT.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: 0-RTT is designed to accelerate the throughput at the establishment of a connection. There are cases where 0-RTT alone does not improve the time to service. Moreover, additionnal information could be forwarded to the server to adapt the initial transport parameters.
This memo proposes a solution where an additional parameter is registered during the 1-RTT phase to improve the initial throughput during subsequent 0-RTT.

section.title: Rule of the 0-RTT
section.t: The goal of this section is to recall how 0-RTT connections differ from 1-RTT connections.
Moreover, QUIC connection establishment relies on TLS ticket management discussed in and .

0-RTT connections are initiated by QUIC clients. Prior to that, the server MUST have provided a NewSessionTicket . The server may provide different values for transport parameters for use in the new connection and MUST NOT change transport parameters that are smaller that the initial values . Transport parameters that are exploited in the 0-RTT are related to the flow control of the streams but do not precise congestion control values that could be recommended.

section.title: Adapt the transport initialization for the 0-RTT connections
section.t: Transport parameters that are exploited in the 0-RTT are related to the flow control of the streams but do not precise congestion control values that could be recommended. This memo proposes a solution where an additional parameters are registered during the 1-RTT phase to improve the initial throughput of the 0-RTT.

The server measures the RTT and the bottleneck bandwidth during the 1-RTT connection. Based on heuristics, the server can detect that the client is on a high BDP link. The server stores in the session ticket a value of the IW which will increase the initial throughput when reconnecting. In this case, packets MUST be paced out to avoid important bursts of data in the network.

When the client re-establishes the session using a 0-RTT phase the server receives the session ticket and decides or not . When the server re-establishes the session it resuses the IW parameter it computed during the 1-RTT phase.

section.title: Benefits on adapting slow-start in high BDP networks
section.t: QUIC connections can hardly be split as TCP connections can be to adapt the inadequate slow-start to high BDP use-cases. As one example, PEP RFC 3135 are commonly deployed in SATCOM infrastructure for that purpose. This results in an improved quality-of-experience for web browsing users . As of today, we can expect the congestion control is QUIC to exhibit the same performance trends than those of TCP versions deployed today.
The approched follows somehow the proposal of which performance has been shown to be interesting for both high BDP and more common BDP .
